content:
Nice clash.

Only issues I found were:
1. "From the data gathered from quadrants" -> "quadrats"
2. With the rounding, you should clarify that trailing zeroes are to be kept, e.g. "1.20" not "1.2".

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems well or perhaps overly explained, the solution is easy to figure out and the problem seems nicely thought out.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This clash is simple to implement but will require some time to understand. Good for testing clashers' speed of understanding.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It‚Äôs a damn good puzzle

Nice straightforward puzzle, but it took me a few read-throughs to understand everything.

Instead of "an organism", I think specifying a particular organism would make the problem sound more engaging and concise! For example, consider the chosen organism to be an axolotl:

"You're a biologist studying the biodiversity of axolotls! <explain quadrat sampling> From the quadrat data, you can calculate:
- <<Species frequency:>> the <<percentage>> of quadrats containing axolotls
- <<Species density:>> the <<total number>> of axolotls found, divided by the <<total area>> of all quadrats.
- <<Percentage cover>> (for a quadrat): the <<number>> of axolotls found, divided by the <<area>> of the quadrat, multiplied by {{100}}."

Also, you can consider making each quadrat a visual input :) That would also follow the actual definition of percentage cover in quadrat sampling. A simple MxN grid of character strings should suffice.

Goal
* Please delete "[[a]]" in the definition of species frequency because "number of quadrats where the desired organisms is found" is NOT [[a]].

* Given that the formulae have been described clearly in words, please remove all the formulae.

* After removing the formulae, please also delete "[[q]]" in the definition of "percentage cover", as [[q]] will no longer be defined. (And it's ok not to define it, because the formula for the area of a rectangle is very basic knowledge).

* Please change "square" to "rectangular" as a quadrat's length and width can be different in this clash.

Input
* Please rewrite Lines 1 and 2 as follows:

<<Line 1>>: An integer [[n]] for the total number of quadrats.
<<Line 2>>: Two space-separated integers [[x]] and [[y]] for the length and the width of every quadrat to be studied.

(Also note "space-separated": because the cases and the stub generator will be modified accordingly. More details below.)

* Why is [[b]] provided as an input when it's not used in the calculation? Please remove it to avoid confusion.

* Next n lines: Please rewrite it in a similar way to Line 1 as illustrated above.

Cases
* The use of brackets in inputs doesn't seem necessary, other than introducing extra parsing which doesn't fit naturally with the problem (counter-example: coordinates). Please change all inputs where brackets are used to space-separated integers.

Stub generator
* Please change the following lines:

Line 2: read x:int y:int
Line 4: loop n read a:int

Output
* (optional) It's not easy to read the output because it's very long and scrolling is required. Suggest to split the output into 3 separate lines.

* Please format "Species frequency is", "%, species density is", "and mean percentage cover is" and "%." as {{constants}}, and remove all the quotation marks.

* Please change "is an integer, not a float" to "should be rounded to the nearest integer".

Cases
* In the names of the cases, please change "quadrants" to "quadrats".

Thanks.

I believe i have implemented all these changes, although im not sure if the ‚ÄúOutput‚Äù section was properly fixed by using {{constants}}. Thank you for the suggestions and they have been very helpful as this is my first contribution.

Thank you for the suggestions! I have edited the statement section following some of ur points in order to make it more easily readable and understandable. 

Regarding the converting the numerical output of the quadrat data into a visual output, how would that look like in the Input section? I can see how the input would look like but how would I change the:
"Line 1: An integer n for total number of quadrats
Line 2: Two space-separated integers x and y for the length and width of every quadrat to be studied
Next n lines: An integer a for the number of desired organisms found in that quadrat"
accordingly?
Thanks for the comment, should be fixed now. However, I will say that the second one isn‚Äôt necessarily an issue, as it should already be implied, quite literally how significant figures work
But you stated '2 decimal places' not significant figures... Most coding languages will solve '(2.10002).round(2)' as '2.1' rather than '2.10', meaning you end up needing sprintf to make this work.

Whoops thats my bad, forgot the language i used in my own contribution, you‚Äôre completely right. I think stating significant figures would have been more appropriate but as i included you‚Äôre suggestion, it should be no longer necessary

Just got this in a clash now and I got confused and thought sf was rounded to nearest integer.
This bit could be more clear:
"[[sf]] is rounded down to <<nearest integer>>"
->
"[[sf]] is <<rounded down>> to nearest integer"

I was thinking more in line with:

<<Next [[n]] x [[x]] lines:>> [[n]] quadrats as string grids, each containing [[x]] rows of strings. Each input row has exactly [[y]] characters, where {{o}} represents exactly one Dumbo Octopus in the quadrat.

<<Example Input>>
2
3 3
__o
_oo
___
o__
___
oo_

So each quadrat (visualised) is

__o      o__
_oo      ___
___       oo_

I like this idea, but would this cause the problem to be even more harder/longer? I realize understanding the question would take time, and adding string/list comprehension might cause it to take too long

It would create an extra step to count the number of organisms (e.g. row.count('o')), so in that sense, yes it will make the clash slightly harder. It does however help to add a visual element to the clash, which might help with understanding.

Feel free to decide which approach is best for your clash :) My main concern was with the ambiguity of "an organism", which you've mostly already resolved. Could you update the title of your clash accordingly? Thank you.
Ive changed the title, I shall think about the other idea you provided, thanks for the feedback
Thanks once more, is there a specific reason it should be formatted as such? Or is this just something thats commonly agreed upon

The formatting is the usual practice, and fits the purpose of the text (variables are formatted as variables, constants are formatted as constants, etc).

More details of the formatting syntax here:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement

I'll proceed to review your contribution again.

Goal
* Please delete "[[c]]" in the definition of species frequency.

* Please delete "[[m]]" and "[[r]]" in the definition of species density.

Output
* Line 2: Please delete "%".

* sf: Please change "rounded" to "rounded down".

Cases
* Test 4: please change "quadrants" to "quadrats".

* Please add a pair of cases where rounding down [[sf]] gives a different result from simple rounding of [[sf]].

Thanks.
All the changes have been made

Sorry, just two more issues:

Cases
* Test 3, could you change "0.1" in Line 2 of the output to "0.10"?

* Test 1, Validator 1, Test 3: Please remove all trailing newlines in input.

Thanks.

These should now be added as well. The change from "0.1" to "0.10" required an additional 2 lines of code to check for significancy of SD, but it wasn't much. Should I add another test case with this situation to ensure the user's code maintains the significancy of SD?
Yes, it's better if you can add another pair of cases üòä
Also, in Goal section, suggest to add "of all quadrats" to the end of the definition of [[sd]] to avoid misinterpretation. Thanks.
Just added a new test case. I had added ‚Äúof all quadrats‚Äù to the wrong sectioj of the [[sd]] definitioj but it should all be fixed now
All right now. Thank you. üôÇ
